doc.name: mobileComposeHtmlMail
doc.summary: Opens a new email message in the user's email program.

examples.example: mobileComposeHtmlMail "Test E-mail", "guido@example.net",,, "This is the bold e-mail body text", tAttachment

description.overview: Use the mobileComposeHtmlMail command to create an HTML email message with attachments from within a stack on iOS or Android.

parameter.name: subject
parameter.description: The subject line of the email.

parameter.name: recipients
parameter.description: A comma delimited list of email addresses to be placed in the 'To' field.

parameter.name: ccs
parameter.description: A comma delimited list of email addresses to be placed in the 'CC' field.

parameter.name: bccs
parameter.description: A comma delimited list of email addresses to be placed in the 'BCC' field.

parameter.name: body
parameter.description: The HTML body text of the email.

parameter.name: attachments
parameter.description: Either empty to send no attachments, a single attachment array or a one-based numeric array of attachment arrays to include. The attachments parameter consists of either a single array, or an array of arrays listing the attachments to include. A single attachment array should consist of the following keys:

option.description: The binary data to attach to the email (not needed if a file is present).
The filename of the file on disk to attach to the email (not needed if data present).

description.value:
Upon completion of a compose request, the result is set to one of the following:
* sent - the email was sent successfully
* cancel - the email was not sent, and the user elected not to save it for later
description.comments:
This command interfaces with the iOS and Android mail composition interface
If you specify a file for the attachment, the engine tries to use the least amount of memory by asking the operating system to only load it from disk when the file is needed. Therefore, using mobileComposeHtmlMail should be the preferred method when attaching large amounts of data to an e-mail.
For example, sending multiple attachments may be done like this:
put "Hello World!" into tAttachments[1]["data"]
put "text/plain" into tAttachments[1]["type"]
put "Greetings.txt" into tAttachments[1]["name"]
put "Goodbye World!" into tAttachments[2]["data"]
put "text/plain" into tAttachments[2]["type"]
put "Farewell.txt" into tAttachments[2]["name"]
mobileComposeHtmlMail tSubject, tTo, tCCs, tBCCs, tBody, tAttachments
Some devices are not configured with e-mail sending capability. To determine if the current device is, use the mobileCanSendMail function. This returns true if the mail client is configured.
Once the mobileComposeHtmlMail command is called, you have no more control over what the user does with the message. They are free to modify the message and the addresses as they see fit.
